{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3491760,"name":"FredK","username":"FredK","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/71e660/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T17:55:10.199Z","cooked":"

We’re thinking of running a belt inside a 1x2 arm and cannot find a lot about it searching here. Specifically the driven pulley would be inside the 1x2 and the other pulley on the intake. It seems like a 16mm pulley inside would be best so there’s less chance of the belt popping off. Any experience or thoughts would be appreciated.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T17:55:10.199Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":236,"readers_count":235,"score":52.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483407,"topic_slug":"any-advice-for-running-timing-belts-inside-1x2s","display_username":"FredK","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31768,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/any-advice-for-running-timing-belts-inside-1x2s/483407/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3491767,"name":"Dominick Ferone","username":"Dominick_Ferone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dominick_ferone/{size}/236622_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T18:01:19.828Z","cooked":"

Some things you can do include removing flanges and using the tube to trap the belt, or using timing stock and machining your own pulley with if needed. (We have done this while including an indent to allow the bearing to press into it from one side.)
We ordered our pulley stock from SDSPI

We have done both 9mm and 15mm belts.

We used to do this for our drivetrain before switching to swerve, as well as in other applications. I recommend using the largest pulley that will fit in the tube so that you have the greatest possible tooth engagement. If the pulley is wide enough, you do not need flanges. The belt will be constrained by the walls of the tube. You can machine your own pulleys from pulley stock, or 3D print them. Here is a post I made on our 2019 drivetrain, with links to our CAD: Belt In Tube West Coast Drive Design Feadback - #19 by Chris_Ely

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T18:23:54.615Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":191,"readers_count":190,"score":83.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483407,"topic_slug":"any-advice-for-running-timing-belts-inside-1x2s","display_username":"Christopher Ely","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/belt-in-tube-west-coast-drive-design-feadback/384296/19","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Belt In Tube West Coast Drive Design Feadback","clicks":16}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13683,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Alumni & Mentor, FRC #3414"},"post_url":"/t/any-advice-for-running-timing-belts-inside-1x2s/483407/3","custom_user_title":"Alumni & Mentor, FRC #3414","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3491846,"name":"Crystal","username":"CIM","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cim/{size}/3861_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T19:30:33.300Z","cooked":"

This doesn’t come up as often anymore, because any team that can do this is generally going to be doing swerve now. But if you want to pursue this route, here is how my old team would do this:

  • 15mm wide belts are a must
  • 24T pulleys were also necessary to avoid issues with belt skipping or stripping
  • Machine bearing holes to exact center-to-center distances - it is easy to over or under-tension a belt so we preferred to make this “mistake-proof”
  • A single flangeless pulley wide enough for 2 belts was used - taking up the entire width of the drive tube. If you use 1.5" wide tube, you would need to cut a 1.25" diameter counterbore into these pulleys to allow for bearing clearance.

To achieve both of these requirements, a 3x1.5" drive tube was typically used. The 3" tube allows for enough clearance to allow for rivets to the top and bottom of the tube - this allows for gusseting to hold the frame together. Obviously the bigger tube came with a weight penalty but we were generally willing to put up with that.

The result was a system that was more or less entirely maintenance free for the whole season.

I think the OP was interested in doing this for an arm. However, it is good to point out what will survive drive-train levels of abuse so people know what they can/can’t get away with.

My team ran belt-in-tube for an arm in 2023. We used Rev ION stuff including MAXTube and just followed the Belt-In-Tube example located here: Medium Complexity | ION BUILD SYSTEM
Onshape
